author: Jasper Hamill
title: Have you got the booze bug? Scientists discover brain mutation could turn revellers into alcoholics
text:
When you see a drunken young man or woman slumped on the street , it's easy to say they are wholly responsible for their sorry state.
But new research has indicated binge-drinking and alcoholism could be caused by a tiny change in revellers' brains.
Scientists at the Stanford University School of Medicine claimed "malfunctions" in a neural enzyme could tip party animals over the edge and turn them into full-blown alchoholics.
Jun Ding, assistant professor of neurosurgery, identified a chemical called ALDH1a1 which has a fascinating effect in the brains of mice, as well as humans.

When the booze bug's activity was blocked in rodents' brains, they become thirsty for more alcohol.
But when they are fed more of the enzyme, they appeared to drink less.
Removing ALDH1a1 from the brain has a similar effect to binge drinking, scientists said, making the mice seek out more alcohol and making them more likely to become addicts.
Giving mice more of the enzyme has the opposite effect.

Ding's research suggests ALDH1a1 is involved in the production of a chemical called GABA which may stop humans getting addicted to the "reward" chemical dopamine, which is produced when humans do something pleasurable.
'All of us normally encounter countless reward-inducing situations without getting addicted,” he said.
Yee-hah: Booze Britain in full swing
"Every time I publish a paper, my dopamine-producing nerve cells go crazy, but I don't get addicted. Why not?"
Mutations in ALDH1a1 may effect the action of GABA and "predispose some people to alcoholism by disabling this brake on our reward machinery", a Stanford spokesman added.
